title: The Ascension and Apostolic Commission
shortSummary: Acts chapter 1 details the final instructions of Jesus to His apostles before His ascension into heaven. It highlights the promise of the Holy Spirit, the apostles’ preparation through prayer, and the selection of Matthias to replace Judas Iscariot, setting the foundation for the early church’s mission.
timeline: c. AD 30-33 - The Ascension of Jesus and the Early Church Preparation

keyCharacters.name: Jesus Christ
keyCharacters.description: The risen Lord who instructs His apostles about the coming Holy Spirit and ascends to heaven.

keyCharacters.name: Peter
keyCharacters.description: The leading apostle who addresses the disciples regarding Judas’ betrayal and leads the selection of a new apostle.

keyCharacters.name: Matthias
keyCharacters.description: Chosen by casting lots to replace Judas Iscariot as an apostle and witness of Jesus’ resurrection.

keyCharacters.name: Theophilus
keyCharacters.description: The recipient of Luke’s writings, addressed in the opening verse as the one for whom the treatise was written.

definitions.definition: Another term for the Holy Spirit, the third Person of the Trinity who empowers believers for witness and service.
The event of Jesus Christ being taken up into heaven in bodily form after His resurrection.
The spiritual immersion and empowerment by the Holy Spirit promised by Jesus to His followers.
Meaning 'Field of Blood,' the name given to the field purchased with Judas’ betrayal money.

outline.heading: Introduction and Promise of the Holy Spirit
outline.description: Luke recounts Jesus’ ministry and His command to the apostles to wait in Jerusalem for the promised Holy Spirit baptism, distinguishing it from John’s water baptism.

outline.heading: The Question of the Kingdom and Jesus’ Response
outline.description: The apostles inquire about the restoration of Israel’s kingdom, but Jesus redirects their focus to the coming empowerment by the Holy Spirit to be His witnesses worldwide.

outline.heading: The Ascension of Jesus
outline.description: Jesus is taken up into heaven before the apostles’ eyes, with angels assuring them He will return in the same manner.

outline.heading: The Apostles’ Return and Prayerful Unity
outline.description: The apostles return to Jerusalem and devote themselves to prayer with one accord, including women and Jesus’ family, demonstrating early church unity.

outline.heading: The Replacement of Judas Iscariot
outline.description: Peter leads the disciples in fulfilling Scripture by selecting Matthias to replace Judas, emphasizing the importance of faithful witness from Jesus’ baptism to His ascension.

application: Trust in God’s timing and promises, especially regarding the work and empowerment of the Holy Spirit in your life.
Commit to prayer and unity with fellow believers as foundational for effective ministry and spiritual growth.
Recognize the importance of faithful witness to Christ’s resurrection and obey God’s instructions even when full understanding is not given.
Seek God’s guidance in decisions, relying on prayer and Scripture to discern His will.

keyVerses.text: But ye shall receive power, after that the Holy Ghost is come upon you: and ye shall be witnesses unto me both in Jerusalem, and in all Judaea, and in Samaria, and unto the uttermost part of the earth.
keyVerses.significance: This verse outlines the mission and empowerment of the church through the Holy Spirit.

keyVerses.text: And when he had spoken these things, while they beheld, he was taken up; and a cloud received him out of their sight.
keyVerses.significance: It records the ascension of Jesus, confirming His exaltation and return to the Father.

keyVerses.text: These all continued with one accord in prayer and supplication, with the women, and Mary the mother of Jesus, and with his brethren.
keyVerses.significance: Demonstrates the early church’s commitment to prayer and unity in the face of uncertainty.

keyVerses.text: And they gave forth their lots; and the lot fell upon Matthias; and he was numbered with the eleven apostles.
keyVerses.significance: Shows the importance of orderly leadership and God’s sovereign choice in the early church.
